query:
I’m doing Transcontinental Race. I have a bike already; recommend the rest (tyres/gearing/bags). I’m 61, based in the Netherlands. Rough washboard and chunky gravel.
Preferences: Tyres: 32–38mm. Wide range gearing needed for steep climbs. Avoid electronic shifting.
Must-haves: Must include puncture protection strategy.; Must include a wide gear range.
Avoid:

candidates.name: : Kees Overboom
candidates.summary:
o 44mm tires. They have low rolling resistance but hopefully provide me with the grip I need on the non-tarmac surfaces.
Ed Schinkel
Name
: Ed Schinkel | Event: Race Around the Netherlands GX 2023 | EventKey: race-around-netherlands

candidates.name: Johnny Uitterhoeve
candidates.summary: Johnny Uitterhoeve | 42 | 's-Heer Arendskerke | Focus Atlas 8.9 carbon. SRAM Rival eTap AXS, 40*10-44, DT Swiss GR1600 tubeless wheels, Adventure Rack for the luggage and good mood for the energy! | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 45mm-50mm | I'll try to sleep on a Sea To Summit UltraLight Mat. Hopefully the NOMAD Pegasus 340 keeps me warm at night. My head lays down on a simple but very useful inflatable pillow from Forclaz (tip!). I've different types of bags for clothes and a AGU frame bag. I will try to find my way with a Bryton Rider 800. Eat everything that cross my path, so be careful! | Event: Race Around The Netherlands GX 2025 | EventKey: race-around-netherlands

candidates.name: Tim Hoogendijk
candidates.summary:
Tim Hoogendijk | 42 | Amsterdam | Canyon Ultimate CF SL8 (2019), Shimano Ultegra mechanical groupset (52/36 and 11-30 cassette), Mavic wheels with 30mm Conti GP5000 (tubes), Selle Italia SLR boost gravel saddle, Profile Design 4525 aerobars. And a Redshift stem for all those bumpy brick roads. | Acepac bottle bag, Apidura top tube bag. Main item is a Tailfin Aeropack, stuffed to the brim with food, repair kit, toiletries and an emergency bivy. It looks like the weather can be anything from 19 degrees with blue skies to 6 degrees with rainstorms, so I'll probably bring cold and wet weather clothing. Front lights are from Lezyne, rear lights Garmin and Bontrager. I use my trusty Wahoo Elemnt Bolt for navigation.
Richard Sharp | Event: Race Around the Netherlands 2024 | EventKey: race-around-

candidates.name: Matthieu Lifschitz
candidates.summary:
o never cut the race and stay outside, Hotels, except for a "ravito", are only in case of no shelters in very bad weather or in case of illness. I especially love to have several little bags instead of one or two big. More useful, and easy to find something. I'll be wearing a full Café du Cycliste kit, especially with the Audax range which is dedicated for long distance ride and is great for it! Wahoo Roam for navigation and a iPhone 11 Pro as backup, and obviously sound system.
Considering the incredible mountains we are going to cross, I will take a small Ricoh GR3 to get some nice pictures. My ultimate weapon is a range of playlists who mix discoid parts, some Stevie Wonder or Prince masterpieces with a bunch of golden age hip hop and a lot of other catchy curiosities as riding partner.

candidates.name: Jochen Böhringer
candidates.summary:
Jochen Böhringer | 45 | Tamm, Germany | ORBEA ORCA M11ELTD PWR | Road | Carbon | 700c (29") | 30-34mm | I'm riding a mix of bag brands. But what I love in particular is my new cyclite aerobar bag because it perfectly fits my aerobars and provide plenty of space for items that I can even access while riding the bike.
I will go for batteries instead of a dynamo hub because I expect the race duration to be easily coverable with one big battery of my Lupine Piko (will also charge my wahoo and mobile phone with it). See you on the "unknown" road :-) | Event: The Unknown Race 2025 | EventKey: unknown-race

candidates.name: Paolo Capozzi
candidates.summary:
mm. They are sleek but are designed for the long distance and have a “nominal life span” of 10000km. Hopefully this will give me some more margin against punctures.
I’m carrying a full sleeping kit with cumulus xlite sleeping bag, vango air mat and msr e-bivy. Though I hope to sleep mostly in hotels. For warmth I have the Albion ultra light insulated jacket and a Rapha brevet gilet plus arm and leg warmers, buff, gloves. And of course a full rain kit.
“Luxury” bit is a spare pair of bib shorts with totally different padding to show my bottom skin some love. | Event: Trans Pyrenees Race 2025 | EventKey: trans-pyrenees-race

candidates.name: : Max
candidates.summary:
: Max | 37 | Arnhem, Netherlands | The classic Surly Straggler 700c, 1x11 SRAM Rival 42t in the front and 11t-46t SunRace cassette in the back, combined with mechanical Avid bb7 disc brakes. Carbon Hunt 4 season gravel x-wide wheels with a SON28 dynamo and Edelux II light upfront and a rearlight, including B&M charging device. Tire choice for this race are Terravail 42mm Cannonball upfront and a more slick 42mm Washburn for the rear wheel. Salsa Cowchipper wide bars and Brooks cambium saddle. | My good old Ortlieb saddle, frame and possible handlebar bag. Not sure about the last one. I made a adjustment to the framebag so I can carry an extra 1.8L Apidura bladder and hose. I bought a Topstone Wishbone to be able to mount 2 bottlecages on the back (not in picture).
Benjamin Wessel
Name
: Be

candidates.name: Marcos de Paiva Bueno (aka Bikesutras)
candidates.summary:
ery packs, charger and cables. Tools: Topeak survival kit and tyre pressure gauge, Lyzene pump, zip ties, duct tape, spokes and nipples, sealant, nitrile gloves, sponge/scrubber, spare tube, CO2 and chain links.Passport and other documents
Apidura race saddle bag with warm layers: Gilet, leggings and extra merino socks. Rain gear: Gore-Tex jacket and trousers, waterproof overmitts and overshoes. Ortovox ultralight bivy and Abus lock. Apidura Packable Musette bag for carrying food and mid-ride essentials when needed.
The total bike and gear weight without food and water is 16kg and the rider weight is confidential lol.
Mike Lane | Event: Transpyrenees 2021 | EventKey: trans-pyrenees-race

candidates.name: Sergey Shulubin
candidates.summary:
ndlebars for long-distance cycling, but fine for carrying heavy loads when touring. For bedding I have a sleeping mat made of thermal insulation material, a bivvy bag, a safety blanket, and a couple of garbage bags.
I’m also carrying a lot of tools, spare parts, and so on, so the whole setup is quite heavy. But after its first 600 km on the way to the start of TPR, it’s holding up alright. | Event: Trans Pyrenees Race 2025 | EventKey: trans-pyrenees-race

candidates.name: Brian Alder
candidates.summary: Brian Alder | 60 | Takaka | My XL Santa Cruz Stigmata sports handy inframe storage, a 36T chainring paired with 11S 10-42 cassette and Di2 XT shifting. Schwalbe G-One RS 45 up front and Hutchinson Caracal 40mm rear so I can enjoy the gravel parcours. Aero bars for a bit of respite. | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 40-44mm | Bags by Apidura, taking a sleeping bag and mat and some warm kit for the big Pyrenean descents. Battery lights with a bunch of spares. Hoping my new POC bibs look after my backside! | Event: Trans Pyrenees Race 2025 | EventKey: trans-pyrenees-race

candidates.name: Jack Yates
candidates.summary: Jack Yates | 33 | Edinburgh | Trek Checkpoint, GRX with 46/30 and 11-40, Conti Terra Hardpack in 50mm, and a Kasai FS dynamo. Aero bars might be dead weight but they're comfortable. Some people regretted choosing gravel bikes last year, but I got through my first ultra on this bike a couple of months ago so I'm going with something that I know won't cause bike fit/comfort issues | Gravel | Aluminium | 700c (29") | 50mm+ | A few layers and tools in the frame bag, misc. bits and food in the top tube bag, bivvy and sleeping bag at the back. My other saddle bag split apart on Trans Alba and this one is partially ripped, so let's see how much kit I still have at the end! | Event: The Land Between 2025 | EventKey: the-land-between

candidates.name: Jochen Böhringer
candidates.summary:
my big handlebar bag. That should improve bike handling and aero dynamics. Looking forward to test it on this demanding track.
My power meter will help me not to over pace at the beginning and kick my ass when watts drop too much during the race. I will go for a SON dynamo hub setup with kLite front light to be able to ride at night and charge my garmin, mobile phone and AXS batteries during the day as well.
Matt Schweiker | Event: Trans Balkan Race 2024 | EventKey: trans-balkan-race

candidates.name: Dominik Ramin
candidates.summary:
ere 1.5. and groundsheet (and I might bring a tarp because I plan on sleeping outside only).
Add-ons: Rab Xenair Jacket (if it gets too cold), Gore Spinshift jacket and Endure pants (if it gets too wet).
Navigation with Garmin Edge 1040 solar (Edge 830 + FR955 solar as a backup).
Team overpacker also carries bagloads of other stuff... Complete ready to race setup-weight 17,8 kg (excluding food+drinks though...)
Luxury item: small towel
Lucky item: "Devil's Loop" bidon | Event: Three Peaks Bike Race 2025 | EventKey: three-peaks-bike-race

candidates.name: Eline van Straalen
candidates.summary: Eline van Straalen | 40 | Amsterdam, The Netherlands | This is my first ultra-endurance race and I'll be riding my Canyon Endurace WMN AL Disc 8.0. Bought it in June last year and have ridden 12,000km on it since. I'll be running 650b wheels (because those are standard on the Endurace 2XS frame size) and Schwalbe One Pro TLE 650x28C tires. Added Profile Design Sonic Ergo 50a aerobars with 70mm risers for extra comfort. My saddle is a Specialized Power Pro Mimic. Using the Tailfin AeroPack X Rigid Seat Pack for main storage and an Apidura Top Tube and Apidura Handlebar Racing Pack for easy access storage (mostly for food and rain jacket). I have a Revelate Designs Feedbag for all the Haribo. | The weather forecast looks pretty wet so I've abandoned my original bivvy plans and instead will r

candidates.name: Amelia Linnett
candidates.summary:
Amelia Linnett | 32 | Barcelona | I own exactly one bicycle: an Oxford Bike Works Expedition that is beautifully optimised for touring and that I have attempted to coerce into what I'm telling myself is a suitable setup for TCRno11, mostly by taking off any components I don't absolutely need (kickstand, mudguards, rack...). | Steel | 50mm+ | My kit list is pretty standard (required items plus emergency bivvy + mat, basic layers for weather, first aid & repair kits), leaning towards the minimal in a probably futile attempt to compensate for how heavy the bike already is.
Aside from the bicycle itself, the least conventional item is probably the CrankTank4, which saves me from my least favourite cycling activity (reaching down for water bottles). It also serves as a reliable conversation sta

candidates.name: Matthias Wellershoff
candidates.summary:
lle Handlebar bag. I will be wearing a mix of clothes from Cafe du Cycliste and Tanline along with my Suplest Crosscountry Performance shoes (which might also be my favourite bit of kit for the journey). My favourite gear ratio has to be 34-28 since I like to ride uphill and enjoy the comfort of knowing that I am able to shift down another gear (to 34-32).
Ulrich „uba“ Bartholmoes | Event: Transpyrenees 2021 | EventKey: trans-pyrenees-race

candidates.name: Jan-Dick den Das
candidates.summary: Jan-Dick den Das | 61 | LANDSMEER | Giant Revolt from 2019, wheels also from Giant, carbon wheels also from Giant. I will ride with Pirelli Cinturato Classic Gravel. I also used these during Torino - nice and they were very good | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 45mm-50mm | Bags are a mix of Apidura and Miss Grape. Lights front Ravemen PR2400. To navigate I will use the Garmin Edge 830 and I use a Garmin battery pack. Just to be on the safe side I have also my Garmin Etrex 32 with me. | Event: the Capitals By PedAlma 2025 | EventKey: capitals-by-pedalma

candidates.name: Max Hopf
candidates.summary: Max Hopf | 33 | Steyr, Austria | Cube Nuroad C62 Pro from 2023, Shimano GRX single speed 11-42T and 40T in the front, Schwalbe G-One Allround Performance tires with 40mm width, aerobars for more comfort and speed :) | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 40mm-44mm | Waterproof bags from Deuter (frame bag and saddle pack), top tube bag from Zefal, food pouch from Zefal, lights from Lyzene and Garmin 530 edge computer, powerbank, spare parts. No sleeping setup. Spare clothes and warm stuff. Plenty of gels, energy bars, nuts and Haribo :p | Event: The Unknown Race 2025 | EventKey: unknown-race

candidates.name: Dries van der Kleij
candidates.summary:
Dries van der Kleij | 44 | Belgium | Specialized Crux Comp. Decided to buy this bike as both a light climbing bike and a bike for some gravel here in my home playground. But after riding it for a couple of months found it quiet spectacular as a general do-it-all racebike, which made me opt for this bike over my Trek Domane also for this Unknown Race. (Plan to upgrade it to a mullet setup and some better wheels and add a Vecnum suspension stem for a bit of extra comfort for off-road adventures, but for now keeping the standard stuff on it.) | Groupset: SRAM Rival - 42T - 11-44 11speed.
Tyres: Challenge - Strada Bianca Pro HTLR 45mm, low rolling resistance + rather good puncture resistance should be able to take me anywhere.
Bags: mix of Apidura and Cyclite with enough room for a couple of 2

candidates.name: Bart Verheijen
candidates.summary:
Bart Verheijen | 41 | Amsterdam, The Netherlands | I will ride a 2017 Canyon Endurace with Di2 upgrade; custom DT Swiss wheels with SON dynamo hub and Supernova lights; despite the climbing, I still chose to ride the TT bars, there will be serious flatter sections where the increased aero and different hand-positions will be great. | Packing will include all the basic necessities. Some caffeine pills for nightly descents; clothing for wet and cold weather (mountains can get chilly, even in summer) and stuff that's easily combined with eachother. I will generally sleep in hotels or if it's too hot, in the afternoon on a nice piece of grass under a tree. Will bring an emergency blanket and swimming shorts.
Rainer Zeller | Event: Three Peaks Bike Race 2021 | EventKey: three-peaks-bike-race

candidates.name: Grégory Garcia
candidates.summary:
Grégory Garcia | 40 | France | Sauvage LaPiste, Shimano GRX 600 drivetrain (48/31 chainrings and 11/34 cassette), Duke World Runner 25 alloy wheels, Tufo Gravel Speedero 40mm tires on both front and rear. | Topeak frame, saddle, and handlebar bags; Restrap hike-a-bike harness; RockBros top tube bag. I carry two power banks and USB lights, along with my Bryton GPS. The sleeping kit includes a bivy bag and sleeping bag, and for extra luxury, I'll take warm clothes to sleep. The rest consists of a usual waterproof vest and gloves. I've filled the bags with food, mainly mixed fruits, nuts, and date bars. I might also carry a CamelBak.
Ayoub Sahli | Event: Trans Pyrenees Race 2024 | EventKey: trans-pyrenees-race

candidates.name: Dennis Ulm
candidates.summary: Dennis Ulm | 45 | Copenhagen (but spanish) | Introducing my Omnium gravel prototype. I can’t share too many details just yet, but what I can say is that this thing has exceeded expectations straight out of the gate. I'm loving it so far. Really hoping it stays dialed in and delivers across the full race. More to come soon... Yes I love chunky tires, specially the Race Kings, they are fast on the road and compact gravel, so far I'm in love with them. Regarding the drive train it is just a Frankenstein one some GX mtb cranks, Rival AXS and Red calipers, they are the best!!! yeah I'm a Sram guy :) | Gravel | Titanium | 700c (29") | 50mm+ | Nothing fancy when it comes to my saddle and frame bags, just some random gear I pulled together. Since this is my first ultra, I’m still figuring out what

candidates.name: Ralf Hesen
candidates.summary: Ralf Hesen | 38 | Veghel | Colnago G4-X | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 40mm-44mm | No key items. Jus't keep riding with al the things you have. No big specialties. | Event: Race Around The Netherlands GX 2025 | EventKey: race-around-netherlands

candidates.name: Amos Mulder

Amos Mulder | 42 | Utrecht | Ican X-Gravel frameset, Campagnolo (Super) Record shifting with Juin Tech hydraulic brakes, Rotor 2inPower 46-30 crankset + 11-34 cassette for steep hills with tired legs, wide DT-Swiss rims with Hope RS4 + SON28 dynamo hub feeding my lights, Pirelli P-Zero Race TLR 35mm (37mm measured) for some comfort on the Belgian roads. | Apidura Racing top tube pack 2L and frame pack 4L, Cyclite Aero Bag, Tailfin Aeropack Alloy and two Agu snack packs for easy access to lots of food + extra 1L bottle.

Wahoo Elemnt Bolt v2 (+v1 backup) for navigation.
Powerbank for charging my phone and Wahoo.
Ravemen

Aeroplug 3D printed aerobars
A lot of flat roads so bags are stuffed with as much food as i can carry :) | Event: Utrecht Ultra XL 2025 | EventKey: utrecht-ultra

k-Lite race lightning

candidates.name: Franziska Buss
candidates.summary:
Franziska Buss | 35 | Munich | Cube Nuroad C:62 SLT (2024) | I prefer comfort over speed, which is why I've chosen my gravel bike with 38 mm low profile tires (the Rene Herse Barlow Endurance). The bike is equipped with the Sram Eagle XX1 AXS group set (40 T in front, 10-50 in the back). Other than that, it’s just another typical Apidura bikepacking setup mixed with the Cyclite Aero Bag. Since the size of my frame does not allow me to carry enough fluids, I will also be wearing the 3 L USWE hydration pack. My Supernova Airstream and Sigma Buster helmet light will guide me through the night. In the back I trust my Lupine Rotlicht Max as well as my Garmin Varia for busy roads attached to my saddlebag with the Cyclite Radar Mount.
Patrick Bühler | Event: Three Peaks Bike Race | EventKey: thre

candidates.name: Laurens Wolting
candidates.summary:
Laurens Wolting | 40 | Zwolle | Van Nicholas Rowtag | Gravel | Titanium | 700c (29") | 30-34mm | Shimano GRX  Di2.
Deda parabolica aero bars.
Tailfin Aeropack,  Blackburn Framebag, Rab Ultrasphere Sleeping mat, SOL "Emergency" sleeping bag, Sea to Summit reactor sleep ling bag cover, and Down Pillow for comfy nights.
Gorewear rain jacket. Gribbgrib shoe covers
Son 28 dynamo hub. With NC-17 power Converter.
Supernova front and rear lights.
Apidura food pouches and top tubebag.
2x Eline 1L water bottles and 1x Naglene* 1L bottle. (*Not in the picture) | Event: VIA Race 2025 | EventKey: via-race

candidates.name: Aleksej Dolinsek
candidates.summary:
Aleksej Dolinsek | 39 | Slovenia | It | Road | Carbon | 700c (29") | 25-29mm | I
ve packed minimal gear for one big push without any sleep :) 5L saddle bag by Apidura for all the gear I need on the ferry and later in the race. 3L frame bag by ZEFAL to store daily gear and food. Regarding illumination, I
ve been using B&M Ixon Rock in front (works also as a power-bank to charge Wahoo Elemnt Bolt on the go) and Bryton Gardia radar rear light. Key item; a lot of carbs by Nduranz nutrition :) | Event: GranGuanche Audax Road 2025 | EventKey: granguanche-audax-road

candidates.name: Macias Telszewski
candidates.summary:
Macias Telszewski | 47 | Mala Piasnica, Pomorskie, Poland | I ride on Rondo MYLC CF1 2023, which served me well for a few longer and shorter ultra-races so far. I have changed just about everything on the bike, so perhaps I use a Rondo frame with a bunch of upgrades;-) | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 40mm-44mm | I do not travel light on this occasion:
Handlebar bag from Apidura holds my accommodation as in a Nemo Hornet OSMO 1P tent, Malachowski Ultralight 300 sleeping bag, inflatable Fjord Nansen Trekker NG mattress and an NRC foil.
Frame bags carry lots of food and bits and bobs needed daily like airpods or wet wipes.
AeroPack Cargo from Tailfin carries rain/cold gear, first aid kit, workshop items, powerbanks, headlamp and a spare T-shirt if I need to bail out and come back by bus...
M

candidates.name: Chris Simpson
candidates.summary: e tried and tested, super comfy and they work. For a ride of this distance, I'm going comfort, not Aero. Also backing that up with their Dirt Roamer waterproof pants and jacket for the British summer weather. A Patagonia Micropuff jacket and gilet to keep things warm and some nano air pants for sleeping in. Sea to Summit Spark SpI bag for sleeping in backed up with Sea To Summit pad and MSR Bivvy. Powerpack to keep the electrics charged up and will also be running a Patagonia Slope Runner 8L trail running backpack with hydration, to help carry a little more food and water when needed. Mainly though, stashing cornish pasties in it. Backpack and bib shorts pockets will carry the spares I hope I won't need, some bits from Wolf Tooth and Crank Brothers in terms of tools. Some spare tubes, tie

on, my current setup provides enough space for this adventure.
My two favorites are a lightweight bivvy bag that contains a mesh to keep biting midges away and DMR pedals with 3d printed bumpers (shoutout to my mate Martin) that match my shoe for extra support.

candidates.name: Bram Jordens
candidates.summary:
Bram Jordens | 42 | Scherpenheuvel, Belgium | I'm riding a Cube agree SL. A pure racer in carbon and Shimano Ultegra group. It's equipped with a aerobar so I can split the famous Dutch coastal (head)wind. I'll be running Continental Grand Prix tires so I can trust the grip in both rain and dry Dutch pavers. DT Swiss rims to top it off. | I will be wearing a comfortable jersey and bibshort that have already proven their quality during my long workouts. I chose TOPEAK for my bags. I'm planning to sleep wherever I lay my head down. So I have a basic sleeping bag with bivvybag and a thin mattress. Garmin edge will take me on the journey and I have a backup navigation on my smartphone. Maybe I'll take an oldskool paper map with me in case of mayor electronic failure.
Richard de Boer | Event: Ra

It features a Shimano GRX RX810 groupset (46/30, 11-34), which is bomb-proof and will definitely help on the climbs. The setup is completed with Continental GP 5000 35mm tubeless tires. | Gravel | Aluminium | 35mm-39mm | Same as with my bike, I carry my travel bags: an Alpkit handlebar bag, Roswheel and Apidura bags in the frame for the Canyon, and an Ortlieb bag on the seatpost, along with a trail vest. My sleep system is a bivvy bag, which fits entirely in the handlebar bag. | Event: Transcontinental Race No11 | EventKey: transcontinental

g Frame Bag with 2 litre waterpack and some food will allow me to continue riding for longer periods.
A Race Saddle Bag (7l) with some extra clothes

candidates.name: Andy Georges
candidates.summary: cket, rain pants, spare socks, long sleeve, short sleeve, leg warmers, gloves, ... I have no clue what the weather has in store, so I'm bringing a bit of everything. Tools are underneath the down tube. Top tube has pump and electronics, frame bag has spare tubes, food and gels and whatever does not fit elsewhere. | Event: The Unknown Race 2025 | EventKey: unknown-race

candidates.name: Markus Herr
candidates.summary:
Markus Herr | 39 | Germany | I’m riding a 2025 Specialized Epic Hardtail Comp equipped with a SRAM Eagle S-1000 Transmission drivetrain, which eliminates the need for a derailleur hanger. | 50mm+ | My setup is subject to change as the race approaches, especially depending on the weather. Currently, I’m planning to bring the following:
For bags, I’m using an Ortlieb frame bag, an Ortlieb handlebar roll, an Aevor saddle bag, and a Cyclite Race backpack which includes a 2-liter hydration bladder and a Sawyer water filter.
My sleeping system consists of an Outdoor Research Helium bivy, a Thermarest NeoAir UberLite sleeping pad, and a Sea to Summit Spark sleeping bag.
In terms of clothing, I’m bringing a rain jacket from Decathlon. I’ll also have my Bedrock sandals with me as an optional item,

candidates.name: Jelle Hanseeuw
candidates.summary: Jelle Hanseeuw | 41 | Belgium | Orbea Terra | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 40mm-44mm | The touching points will problably be key: a Fizik vento argo adaptive (3D printed) saddle, Deda aero bars (to take on different positions) and Time Atac pedals (comfortable). Further on I went for reliable gear: alu Hunt gravel wheels with Schwalbe G One R tyres (puncture resistant and good both on and offroad). Standard GRX 810 group set with a Rotor outer chainring. 46-31T in the front and 11-32 in the back. | Event: Race Around Rwanda 2025 | EventKey: race-around-rwanda

candidates.name: Wil A-B
candidates.summary:

Pro Missile Aero Bars set up at a comfortable height for a relaxed alternative riding position. Exposure Strada front and Cateye rear lights; and a Garmin 530 for navigation. Finally -and most importantly - some midget gems as a go-to treat and some great tunes to listen to for those low points.
Chris Davis | Event: Pan Celtic Race 2024 |

candidates.name: Tor Hovland
candidates.summary:
Tor Hovland | 50 | Trondheim, Norway | Gavia Terra LTD, a Norwegian brand. | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 35mm-39mm | A lightweight Cumulus sleeping bag, and an even lightweighter Klymit Inertia X Frame pad. Hoping to not use them much!
Helly Hansen Lifa long sleeve UV shirt, and a home-made cap with sun shade for the neck.
Compeed Extreme, Allevyn foam dressings, Xenofit Second Skin, and Avène Cicalfate+, for protecting my sit bones for as long as possible.
My very nice Rogue Panda frame bag was custom made for my Trek Domane, but it fits OK here as well.

query:
For Transcontinental Race, compare these setups for my constraints:
- Option A: gravel bike
- Option B: hardtail
I’m 42, based in the UK. Expect lots of rain and mud.
Constraints: Prioritize puncture resistance. Wide range gearing needed for steep climbs. Bags: minimal (fast & light). Navigation: Garmin only. Avoid ultralight fragile parts.
Tell me which you’d pick and why.

rry sections.  Camel bak 18 litre day bag for the bike carry sections and when I have a large load of food/water on board. candidates.name: : Phil Weaver
candidates.summary:
s liner offer similar warmth. It's also versatile and compact.  Hoping to sleep indoors on night two, but will book it on the fly as won't know in advance how far along the route I'll be.
Electronics - Garmin Edge 530 GPS with phone/RideWithGPS as backup. 2 x 10,000mha power banks. Fenix BC26R front light with spare rechargeable battery. Spare front light - L&M Rando 500.  Rear lights - AAA battery powered Niterider Cherry Bomb 100 plus Cateye 450lm rechargeable. A couple of charging cables and an Anker double USB plug.
Kit - mix of Albion (bibs, Zoa waterproof over-trousers just in case) and Rapha (Brevet jersey, merino undershirt).  Gore waterproof jacket. Giro lightweight gloves. Buff.
Plus spares, tools, toiletries.

candidates.name: Emma Flukes
candidates.summary:
Emma Flukes | 32 | Hobart, Tasmania | Canyon Exceed CF SLX hardtail (Fox Factory 32 SC). candidates.name: Phil Clarke

keep the stuff I want to have easy access to when I'm on the bike, such as the wind jacket or the leg warmers. I might also use the upper side of that bag to store snacks!

query:
For Transcontinental Race, compare these setups for my constraints:
- Option A: gravel bike
- Option B: hardtail
I’m 42, based in the UK. Expect lots of rain and mud.
Constraints: Prioritize puncture resistance. Mechanical shifting only (no electronic). Tyres: 50mm+. I’m undecided between gravel and hardtail. Bags: full bikepacking (frame + saddle + bar roll).
Tell me which you’d pick and why.

framebag will carry mainly food and repair/spares kit. Toptube mostly electronics, powerbank and everything I want to reach quickly.

Front lights are from Lezyne, rear lights Garmin and Bontrager. I use my trusty Wahoo Elemnt Bolt for navigation.

candidates.name: Nick Rotter

ns for fast access like suncream, smartphone and money. In addition I carry Keego Fidlock bottles, easy access also with a frame bag.
The long top tube bag from EVOC is mandatory to keep food accessible.
Speaking of food: wine gums aka Katjes will fuel me hopefully most of the day :D
A hooded rain jacket - the water does not come into the neck - and a long rain pants.
A power bank should do the work to keep my electronics charged, smartphone will do the navigation job once I reached the checkpoints. | Event: The Unknown Race 2025 | EventKey: unknown-race

candidates.name: : Martin Bloch
candidates.summary:
keep the stuff I want to have easy access to when I'm on the bike, such as the wind jacket or the leg warmers. I might also use the upper side of that bag to store snacks!
Last but not least, I'll use a custom built rear rack (which was also built by Cycles Manivelle!). It will carry a 7L dry bag with all the stuff I'll use less often like the down jacket or maybe some spare bib shorts. The rack weighs almost nothing and will prevent the bag from swinging during the climbs.
I'll also carry 2 bottles and might use the 3rd one underneath the frame to store some multitool/spare tube kind of thing.

•Hunt 4season superdura with son dynamo
•pirelli cinturato M 45mm

candidates.name: Matthieu Lifschitz
candidates.summary:
o never cut the race and stay outside, Hotels, except for a "ravito", are only in case of no shelters in very bad weather or in case of illness. I especially love to have several little bags instead of one or two big. More useful, and easy to find something. I'll be wearing a full Café du Cycliste kit, especially with the Audax range which is dedicated for long distance ride and is great for it! Wahoo Roam for navigation and a iPhone 11 Pro as backup, and obviously sound system.
Considering the incredible mountains we are going to cross, I will take a small Ricoh GR3 to get some nice pictures. My ultimate weapon is a range of playlists who mix discoid parts, some Stevie Wonder or Prince masterpieces with a bunch of golden age hip hop and a lot of other catchy curiosities as riding partner.

Shimano MT91 boots, Montane Gaiters, Berghaus Goretex trousers, Paramo Velez smock. Endura lid, Specialized gloves and waterproof work gloves for the rain. Will be taking a meths stove and plenty of food as there may be supply issues on the Northern loop.

candidates.name: : Jacques Brown

I've gone for the M-Wave frame bag and seat pack (11L). It's a tight squeeze for everything I'm packing but I've managed to get everything in, including a small gas cooker and pot set. Rock Bros top tube bag for my spare tube, chain and tools. On the handlebars I've put a basket with a small cooler bag with two compartments. One to keep drinks cold and the other for food. Packing enough liquids is my primary concern, so I'll be carrying roughly 8L of liquids in total spread out between my 3L Camelpac, a custom bottle carrier on the frame, the cooler and frame bag.
GEAR HIGHLIGHTS: For navigation I've gone with the Wahoo Elemnt V2. For power I've chosen a lite foldable solar panel and power bank. So solar by day and power bank by night. All my other gear is pretty much standard gear for rac

Find rider setup examples for Transcontinental Race matching:
Tyres: 32–38mm. 2x drivetrain preferred. Sleep: comfort (bag + pad). Navigation: Garmin only. Avoid suspension (keep it simple).
I’m 49, based in Belgium. Fast tarmac stretches mixed with gravel.

query:
Find rider setup examples for Transcontinental Race matching:
Prioritize puncture resistance. 2x drivetrain preferred. Power: dynamo hub + USB charging. Bags: minimal (fast & light). Mechanical shifting only (no electronic).
I’m 35, based in Switzerland. Fast tarmac stretches mixed with gravel.

query:
I’m doing GB Duro. Optimize for speed (racing), not comfort. I’m 35, based in Switzerland. Rough washboard and chunky gravel.
Preferences: Tyres: 50mm+. Electronic shifting is fine. Avoid electronic shifting.
Must-haves: Must include a wide gear range.
Avoid: Avoid ultralight fragile parts.; Avoid huge tyres (keep it fast).

query:
For Two Volcano Sprint, compare these setups for my constraints:
- Option A: gravel bike
- Option B: hardtail
I’m 37, based in Spain. Fast tarmac stretches mixed with gravel.
Constraints: Tyres: 45–50mm. Wide range gearing needed for steep climbs. Sleep: power naps only (no sleep system). I’m undecided between gravel and hardtail.
Tell me which you’d pick and why.

query:
For Two Volcano Sprint, compare these setups for my constraints:
- Option A: gravel bike
- Option B: hardtail
I’m 49, based in Belgium. Fast tarmac stretches mixed with gravel.
Constraints: Prioritize rolling speed. Electronic shifting is fine. Prioritize puncture resistance.
Tell me which you’d pick and why.

query:
I’m doing Two Volcano Sprint. What would you change for reliability (not speed)? I’m 49, based in Belgium. Rough washboard and chunky gravel.
Preferences: Tyres: 50mm+. Electronic shifting is fine. Bags: rack / Tailfin style. Avoid huge tyres (keep it fast).
Must-haves: Must include puncture protection strategy.
Avoid: Avoid aero bars.; Avoid electronic shifting.

query:
For Two Volcano Sprint, compare these setups for my constraints:
- Option A: gravel bike
- Option B: hardtail
I’m 28, based in Germany. Long night riding, cold temperatures.
Constraints: Prioritize rolling speed. Mechanical shifting only (no electronic). Bags: full bikepacking (frame + saddle + bar roll). Tyres: 2.2–2.4" MTB. I want a rigid bike (no suspension).
Tell me which you’d pick and why.

candidates.name: Tim Flynn
candidates.summary:
Tim Flynn | 36 | Dorchester, UK | Canyon Endurace | I've upgraded to the Tailfin rear rack. So far, it has saved me so much time by eliminating any faff with packing, tightening straps, and searching in the bag. Well worth the extra weight!
Other than that, the wheels are hand-built by Adey Dent from off-the-shelf parts, making them easy to fix in most bike shops. Fitted to them are Michelin 28mm Power Cup TLR tires. I've got a 65mm stack height in my aero bars for all-day comfort and aero gains! I'm not running a handlebar bag as I need to save every watt possible! I have two 750ml water bottles and an emergency packable 1l water bottle in my rear pack. Up front, the lights are the Cateye Amp 1100 and Amp 400. The rear light is the Knog Cobber, along with two wearable Cateyes on the bag.

o never cut the race and stay outside, Hotels, except for a "ravito", are only in case of no shelters in very bad weather or in case of illness. I'll be wearing a full Café du Cycliste kit, especially with the Audax range which is dedicated for long distance ride and is great for it! Wahoo Roam for navigation and a iPhone 11 Pro as backup, and obviously sound system.
Considering the incredible mountains we are going to cross, I will take a small Ricoh GR3 to get some nice pictures. My ultimate weapon is a range of playlists who mix discoid parts, some Stevie Wonder or Prince masterpieces with a bunch of golden age hip hop and a lot of other catchy curiosities as riding partner.

query:
For Dorset Divide, compare these setups for my constraints:
- Option A: gravel bike
- Option B: hardtail
I’m 61, based in the Netherlands. Expect lots of rain and mud.
Constraints: Tyres: 32–38mm. Wide range gearing needed for steep climbs. Prioritize puncture resistance. Navigation: Garmin only.
Tell me which you’d pick and why.

query:
I’m doing GranGuanche Audax Trail. Give me 3 setup archetypes and when to choose each. I’m 61, based in the Netherlands. Fast tarmac stretches mixed with gravel.
Preferences: Tyres: 2.2–2.4" MTB. Mechanical shifting only (no electronic). Sleep: minimal (bivy + quilt). Wide range gearing needed for steep climbs.
Must-haves: Must include a wide gear range.
Avoid:

query:
I’m doing GranGuanche Audax Trail. I have a bike already; recommend the rest (tyres/gearing/bags). I’m 37, based in Spain. Many steep climbs, low cadence.
Preferences: Prioritize puncture resistance. Electronic shifting is fine. Power: dynamo hub + USB charging.
Must-haves: Must include a reliable charging plan.; Must include a wide gear range.
Avoid: Avoid electronic shifting.

candidates.name: Konrad Kowara
candidates.summary:
Konrad Kowara | 45 | Netherlands | Orbea Oiz TR modified for long distance rides - 100mm stem and aero bars mostly for comfort. Fox transfer dropper post to be able to send it on the descents. Things will get steep, so I went with 30t chainring and a 10-50 cassette. | The key item is using Aeroe bag mounts in the back - it’s a little heavier but no tail wag and it gives a lot of clearance for the dropper post. Fun before function.
To make up for the extra weight I’ll pack very light - total sleeping system is just 300g, not planning to camp at elevation.
Emeterio Suarez | Event: GranGuanche Audax Trail 2024 | EventKey: granguanche-audax-trail

candidates.name: Paul Dickens
candidates.summary: on route. My Garmin Edge1030 plus will show me the way (with view ranger phone app as backup) , whilst rear varia RTL515 radar&light and front exposure trace lights will keep me safe (not planning to cycle in the dark) with a 4 port Zendure A8QC external battery charger along to recharge everything overnight. My top tube (snacks), crossbar (waterproofs, lock, gloves, hats, arm warmers, gilet etc) and rear bike bags (down jacket) are from EVOC and handlebar bag is a ROCKBROS (sleeping gear) but I will also be taking a Solomon XA 25 waterproof rucksack to house cooking gear, washing gear, pyjamas (compression topped bottoms for overnight recovery), spare snacks and a 2ltr bladder for water. My Rab down jacket, x-bionic base layer, Castelli perfecto ROS cycling jacket and Gore cycling shorts

candidates.name: Matthieu Lifschitz
candidates.summary:
o never cut the race and stay outside, Hotels, except for a "ravito", are only in case of no shelters in very bad weather or in case of illness. I especially love to have several little bags instead of one or two big. More useful, and easy to find something. I'll be wearing a full Café du Cycliste kit, especially with the Audax range which is dedicated for long distance ride and is great for it! Wahoo Roam for navigation and a iPhone 11 Pro as backup, and obviously sound system.
Considering the incredible mountains we are going to cross, I will take a small Ricoh GR3 to get some nice pictures. My ultimate weapon is a range of playlists who mix discoid parts, some Stevie Wonder or Prince masterpieces with a bunch of golden age hip hop and a lot of other catchy curiosities as riding partner.

query:
I’m doing Further Elements. What would you change for reliability (not speed)? I’m 35, based in Switzerland. Expect lots of rain and mud.
Preferences: Tyres: 2.2–2.4" MTB. Electronic shifting is fine. Bags: minimal (fast & light).
Must-haves: Must include a comfortable cockpit.; Must include a reliable charging plan.
Avoid: Avoid ultralight fragile parts.; Avoid aero bars.

candidates.name: Johnny Baker
candidates.summary: Johnny Baker | 54 | Your bike: | 12l Synchro backpack for day stuff and food. Rab sleeping bag, Klymit mat plus spare socks and Johnson's baby powder stashed away in Revelate bags. Kit includes Nordisk tent in seat pack and MSR pocket rocket stove. (If the forecast is good weather I would just go with a bivvy bag). I'm taking some cool weather kit this year like an extra buff and a Patagonia Micro puff hoodie. Plus I'm packing a full hardshell with a decent hood and goretex shorts and overshoes! Food includes a couple of Firepot meals and a lot of Mountainfuel,  especially their Feel (very) good bars. My Midge net, Happy bum and superb Bite free repellent will be close to hand in a surprisingly weatherproof Mag tank. Electronics include a Garmin Etrex 30 a Zendure battery and some Lithiums

candidates.name: Chris Simpson
candidates.summary: e tried and tested, super comfy and they work. For a ride of this distance, I'm going comfort, not Aero. Also backing that up with their Dirt Roamer waterproof pants and jacket for the British summer weather. A Patagonia Micropuff jacket and gilet to keep things warm and some nano air pants for sleeping in. Sea to Summit Spark SpI bag for sleeping in backed up with Sea To Summit pad and MSR Bivvy. Powerpack to keep the electrics charged up and will also be running a Patagonia Slope Runner 8L trail running backpack with hydration, to help carry a little more food and water when needed. Mainly though, stashing cornish pasties in it. Backpack and bib shorts pockets will carry the spares I hope I won't need, some bits from Wolf Tooth and Crank Brothers in terms of tools. candidates.name: Mathias
candidates.summary: gearing it seemed like the best option. After collecting it myself from customs and fiddling a lot with internal cable routing, I got it mounted onto the bike, even though shifting is sometimes a bit off still. As for the wheels I was looking for a bit wider rims for my planned tubeless setup (Conti terra trail 40mm) and went for the trusted DT Swiss R500db. Combined with a shutter precision dynamo hub, I hope to be prepared to ride through the nights with a 75lux LED frontlight. I soldered a dynamo USB charger to charge my devices on the go, but cooling the circuit did not work out, so I ended up buying a dynamo charger for that reason. For the brakes I went for a hybrid disc brake solution: cable actuated but oil pressured. Finding the right ones to fit the frame was difficult though (f

candidates.name: : Maarten Vanhaverbeke
candidates.summary:
'm a professional bike mechanic, so gear nerding is definitely part of the deal. | Bags are a mix of Apidura framebags (that long top tube bag is brilliant), Revelate Designs feedbags (have tried others, these are just the best in my opinion) and a Ortlieb saddlebag (been using the bigger version for years, trying out the smaller one now). No backpack for me. I prefer a tent over a bivy, so I'll be bringing my Nordisk Lofoten tent strapped to the rather unique load bearing Mason ISO front fender. Sleeping in a Cumulus bag on a Therm-a-Rest pad. Been navigating with Garmin devices for years and probably won't be changing that anytime soon. Bringing a Edge 530 and I have Osmand on my phone as extra/backup.

candidates.name: : Jacques Brown
candidates.summary:
I've gone for the M-Wave frame bag and seat pack (11L). It's a tight squeeze for everything I'm packing but I've managed to get everything in, including a small gas cooker and pot set. Rock Bros top tube bag for my spare tube, chain and tools. On the handlebars I've put a basket with a small cooler bag with two compartments. One to keep drinks cold and the other for food. Packing enough liquids is my primary concern, so I'll be carrying roughly 8L of liquids in total spread out between my 3L Camelpac, a custom bottle carrier on the frame, the cooler and frame bag.
GEAR HIGHLIGHTS: For navigation I've gone with the Wahoo Elemnt V2. For power I've chosen a lite foldable solar panel and power bank. So solar by day and power bank by night. All my other gear is pretty much standard gear for rac

candidates.name: Matthieu Lifschitz
candidates.summary:
o never cut the race and stay outside, Hotels, except for a "ravito", are only in case of no shelters in very bad weather or in case of illness. I especially love to have several little bags instead of one or two big. More useful, and easy to find something. I'll be wearing a full Café du Cycliste kit, especially with the Audax range which is dedicated for long distance ride and is great for it! Wahoo Roam for navigation and a iPhone 11 Pro as backup, and obviously sound system.
Considering the incredible mountains we are going to cross, I will take a small Ricoh GR3 to get some nice pictures. My ultimate weapon is a range of playlists who mix discoid parts, some Stevie Wonder or Prince masterpieces with a bunch of golden age hip hop and a lot of other catchy curiosities as riding partner.

s custom made by Bike Bags UK. The seatpack is from Altura and the feedbags and top tube bag are cheap ebay/amazon items. I will carry Gore Shakedry jacket and maybe waterproof pants but am hoping the weather will be kind.
Sleep system is a SOL bivvy covered with a Gatewood cape if rain is expected. Sea2Summit Spark1 bag with a silk liner, all resting on a Neoair pad. I will have a down jacket and merino leggings for extra warmth off the bike and sleeping.
Lights are dynamo powered K-Lite Ultra front and B&M Secula rear. I will carry backup battery lights but don’t expect to need them. Navigation is with Garmin 1030 using iPhone and Komoot as a ba

my big handlebar bag. That should improve bike handling and aero dynamics. Looking forward to test it on this demanding track.
My power meter will help me not to over pace at the beginning and kick my ass when watts drop too much during the race. I will go for a SON dynamo hub setup with kLite front light to be able to ride at night and charge my garmin, mobile phone and AXS batteries during the day as well.

candidates.name: Karlo Knezevic
candidates.summary: nd a 1.2 L Apidura downtube pack for my repair kit, plus a 1.5 L Restrap top-tube bag for charging cables and accessories and a small Restrap food pouch for gels and gummies. I’m wearing a Salomon ADV Skin 12 L vest with a 1.5 L bladder, giving me 2.8 L of water capacity and room for extra food and a jacket. To power my devices - the Garmin 1030 Plus, inReach Mini 2, Nitecore NU25 headlamp, and Fenix BC05R V2.0 - I’ll use two 20 000 mAh power banks. Overall, the whole setup with food and 2L of water is about 20kg. | Event: GBDURO24 | EventKey: gbduro

query:
I’m doing Tour de Farce. Recommend a complete setup (bike, tyres, drivetrain, bags, sleep, nav). I’m 61, based in the Netherlands. Rough washboard and chunky gravel.
Preferences: Prioritize rolling speed. 2x drivetrain preferred. Mechanical shifting only (no electronic). Bags: rack / Tailfin style. Avoid ultralight fragile parts.
Must-haves: Must include puncture protection strategy.
Avoid: Avoid suspension (keep it simple).

" | 37 | Geldrop, Netherlands | My bike is built around a steel Element frame. The wheels are spoked with 36spokes, dynamo hub and 28mm Continental 5000S2 tyres. The lights I will be using in the front is a Supernova E3 Pro2 and in the back Supernova E3 Tail Light 2. For water supply there are 3 x 750ml bidons. " | 37 | Geldrop, Netherlands | My bike is built around a steel Element frame. The wheels are spoked with 36spokes, dynamo hub and 28mm Continental 5000S2 tyres. query:
I’m doing Tour de Farce. Optimize for speed (racing), not comfort. I’m 61, based in the Netherlands. Long night riding, cold temperatures.
Preferences: Tyres: 32–38mm. Electronic shifting is fine. Prioritize rolling speed. Power: power banks only (no dynamo). Bags: rack / Tailfin style.
Must-haves: Must include lights for night riding.; Must include puncture protection strategy.
Avoid: Avoid suspension (keep it simple).

query:
I’m doing Tour de Farce. Recommend a complete setup (bike, tyres, drivetrain, bags, sleep, nav). I’m 49, based in Belgium. Rough washboard and chunky gravel.
Preferences: Tyres: 2.2–2.4" MTB. 1x drivetrain only. Tyres: 32–38mm. I prefer a hardtail.
Must-haves: Must include a reliable charging plan.
Avoid: Avoid suspension (keep it simple).

The bike is equipped with the Sram Eagle XX1 AXS group set (40 T in front, 10-50 in the back). Other than that, it’s just another typical Apidura bikepacking setup mixed with the Cyclite Aero Bag. Since the size of my frame does not allow me to carry enough fluids, I will also be wearing the 3 L USWE hydration pack. My Supernova Airstream and Sigma Buster helmet light will guide me through the night. In the back I trust my Lupine Rotlicht Max as well as my Garmin Varia for busy roads attached to my saddlebag with the Cyclite Radar Mount.

query:
I’m doing Peninsular Divide. Recommend a complete setup (bike, tyres, drivetrain, bags, sleep, nav). I’m 49, based in Belgium. Fast tarmac stretches mixed with gravel.
Preferences: Tyres: 2.2–2.4" MTB. Wide range gearing needed for steep climbs. Bags: rack / Tailfin style.
Must-haves: Must include a wide gear range.; Must include a reliable charging plan.

candidates.name: Matthieu Lifschitz
candidates.summary:
o never cut the race and stay outside, Hotels, except for a "ravito", are only in case of no shelters in very bad weather or in case of illness. I especially love to have several little bags instead of one or two big. More useful, and easy to find something. I'll be wearing a full Café du Cycliste kit, especially with the Audax range which is dedicated for long distance ride and is great for it! Wahoo Roam for navigation and a iPhone 11 Pro as backup, and obviously sound system.
Considering the incredible mountains we are going to cross, I will take a small Ricoh GR3 to get some nice pictures. My ultimate weapon is a range of playlists who mix discoid parts, some Stevie Wonder or Prince masterpieces with a bunch of golden age hip hop and a lot of other catchy curiosities as riding partner.

candidates.name: : Jacques Brown
candidates.summary:
I've gone for the M-Wave frame bag and seat pack (11L). It's a tight squeeze for everything I'm packing but I've managed to get everything in, including a small gas cooker and pot set. Rock Bros top tube bag for my spare tube, chain and tools. On the handlebars I've put a basket with a small cooler bag with two compartments. One to keep drinks cold and the other for food. Packing enough liquids is my primary concern, so I'll be carrying roughly 8L of liquids in total spread out between my 3L Camelpac, a custom bottle carrier on the frame, the cooler and frame bag.

candidates.name: Paul Dickens
candidates.summary: on route. My Garmin Edge1030 plus will show me the way (with view ranger phone app as backup) , whilst rear varia RTL515 radar&light and front exposure trace lights will keep me safe (not planning to cycle in the dark) with a 4 port Zendure A8QC external battery charger along to recharge everything overnight. No backpack for me. I prefer a tent over a bivy, so I'll be bringing my Nordisk Lofoten tent strapped to the rather unique load bearing Mason ISO front fender. Sleeping in a Cumulus bag on a Therm-a-Rest pad. Been navigating with Garmin devices for years and probably won't be changing that anytime soon. Bringing a Edge 530 and I have Osmand on my phone as extra/backup.

query:
For Peninsular Divide, compare these setups for my constraints:
- Option A: gravel bike
- Option B: hardtail
I’m 61, based in the Netherlands. Many steep climbs, low cadence.
Constraints: Tyres: 50mm+. 2x drivetrain preferred. Power: dynamo hub + USB charging. I’m undecided between gravel and hardtail. Avoid aero bars.
Tell me which you’d pick and why.

Niels Tiaden | 22 | Cape Town | BMC URS | Gravel | Carbon | 700c (29") | 45mm-50mm | This is my BMC URS in its ultra setup.
I am running Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M tyres, 45mm front and 40mm rear. For gearing I am running Sram GX AXS with 10-52/38T gearing.
For lighting I have an exposure Six Pack on the front and a Diablo on the helmet along with an exposure Blaze on the rear.
My saddle bag and top tube bag is full of nutrition (bars/gels/carb mix) and my frame bag has my power bank, battery pack and clothing. I am keeping all my spares in the tool bottle below the frame bag.
I am carrying 2.5L water capacity, 1L on the bike with 1.5L in a hydration pack.
For navigation I am relying on the Garmin 1040 Solar. | Event: GranGuanche Audax Gravel 2025 | EventKey: granguanche-audax-gravel

candidates.name: : Ross Phoenix
candidates.summary:
: Ross Phoenix | 37 | Cornwall | 29er hardtail | Bike
Sram drivetrain with sunrace 11-52 cassette with 32 chainring. Will have me spinning out a lot on the road sections but I’m in no danger of being near the front anyway!
Tt bars because I can’t suffer too much nerve damage at the moment plus I can spin out even sooner on flat sections.
Rockshox Sid fork
Hunt trailwide wheelset

Sleep kit

Probably a Sleepin

candidates.name: Bart Verheijen
candidates.summary:
Bart Verheijen | 41 | Amsterdam, The Netherlands | I will ride a 2017 Canyon Endurace with Di2 upgrade; custom DT Swiss wheels with SON dynamo hub and Supernova lights; despite the climbing, I still chose to ride the TT bars, there will be serious flatter sections where the increased aero and different hand-positions will be great. | Packing will include all the basic necessities. Some caffeine pills for nightly descents; clothing for wet and cold weather (mountains can get chilly, even in summer) and stuff that's easily combined with eachother. I will generally sleep in hotels or if it's too hot, in the afternoon on a nice piece of grass under a tree. Will bring an emergency blanket and swimming shorts.

s a Garmin etrex with an Edge 800 backup. A couple of quick charge batteries & other gubbins stored in a Restrap top tube bag will support these as I move too slow off road for my dynamo! candidates.name: Sergey Shulubin
candidates.summary:
proper 110 BCD cranks I used before, I had to go with 135 BCD. That leaves me with gears of 46x14 and 39x24 — so climbing will be a bit harder than I’m used to.
For the same reason, instead of new bags I had to rely on leftovers from the stolen bike that the thieves left behind: a rear bag that used to be a handlebar bag (easy to reach), and handlebar bags that are basically a Frankenstein mix of several different models. The frame bag was handmade at the very last moment with glue and a needle out of an Ikea bag. The same goes for the front panniers, which I cut from a plastic shopping bag — waterproof and with plenty of space.
The rear rack is a low-pro bullhorn. Not great as ergonomic handlebars for long-distance cycling, but fine for carrying heavy loads when touring. For bedding I ha

candidates.summary: Tim zimmer | 36 | Cologne, Germany | Salsa Cutthroat | Hardtail - Fully Rigid | Carbon | 700c (29") | 45mm-50mm | I'm running a 50mm Schwalbe G-One RX Pro in the front and a 45mm RS in the back. Tubeless, of course. My SRAM AXS Eagle 10-50 cassette coupled with  a 38 tooth chainring will get me up the steepest climbs and a Supernova M99 Dy Pro wired to a SON dynamo hub will turn night to day. My cleats will be locked into a set of Garmin Vector 3 road pedals if the weather is good. I'll swap them for a MTB version if the forecast suggests muddy conditions. My kit is completed by a set of Apidura racing bags inside of which I keep the usual suspects plus a Silca Elettrico Ultimate electronic pump whose ultra compatibility I'm testing this time around. | Event: Taunus Bikepacking No.8 2025 |
